title: Effects of PV transformer energization on power quality
abstract: The penetration of Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) continues to blur the boundary between the tradition ally held definitions of transmission and distribution systems. Increasingly, DERs are being connected at the sub-transmission and distribution voltage levels. As is the case with any new technology, the proliferation of such generation resources has led to certain unforeseen outcomes. This paper examines the effect on the power system (with regards to power quality), of the transformers that are being used to integrate DERs to the system. Two case studies from two different utilities in the United States, pertaining to Solar PV transformer energization are presented. One case study pertains to transformer energization and system unbalance leading to harmonic resonance issues while the other shows distortion around the zero crossing of the voltage caused by ringing during energization of PV transformers connected to solar inverters. A third, simulation case study examines PV transformer energization that excites resonance in systems containing transmission cables. Detailed analyses of the phenomena, underlying causes and mitigation techniques are presented. Finally, shortcomings with respect to modeling techniques and lessons learned in the process have been described. The paper closes with a description of future research avenues and expected work with regards to Power Quality in this field.

Effects of PV Transformer Energization on
Power Quality
Gaurav Singh, Sean McGuinness, Carl Miller, Mark Stephens, and Mark McGranaghan
Electric Power Research Institute
Knoxville, TN 37932
Email: gsingh@epri.com
Abstract—The penetration of Distributed Energy Resources
(DERs) continues to blur the boundary between the tradition-
ally held deﬁnitions of transmission and distribution systems.
Increasingly, DERs are being connected at the sub-transmission
and distribution voltage levels. As is the case with any new
technology, the proliferation of such generation resources has
led to certain unforeseen outcomes. This paper examines the
effect on the power system (with regards to power quality), of
the transformers that are being used to integrate DERs to the
system. Two case studies from two different utilities in the United
States, pertaining to Solar PV transformer energization are
presented. One case study pertains to transformer energization
and system unbalance leading to harmonic resonance issues
while the other shows distortion around the zero crossing of the
voltage caused by ringing during energization of PV transformers
connected to solar inverters. A third, simulation case study
examines PV transformer energization that excites resonance
in systems containing transmission cables. Detailed analyses of
the phenomena, underlying causes and mitigation techniques
are presented. Finally, shortcomings with respect to modeling
techniques and lessons learned in the process have been described.
The paper closes with a description of future research avenues
and expected work with regards to Power Quality in this ﬁeld.
I. I NTRODUCTION
Historically, generation technology (such as Hydro and
thermal based generation) has been centralized in nature,
with generation facilities being located away from the ac-
tual consumers [1]–[3]. Currently, a growing portion of the
power generation is located on distribution systems closer
to customers. This includes PV , wind, fuel cells, combined
heat and power systems and customer demand side resources
(collectively known as Distributed Energy Resources-DERs).
Integrating these distributed resources with the planning and
operation of the distribution system has become one of our
most important challenges.
As is the case with any new technology or idea, this advent
of DERs has led to its own set of problems, some anticipated
and some that were not. The integration of DERs (and as-
sociated problems) is a subject of considerable discussion at
the moment with various CIGRE and IEEE working groups
working on this subject. Some of these issues have been
addressed in IEEE standard 1547 [4] and the interested reader
may refer to the various parts of this standard for further
details. This paper speciﬁcally focuses on Power Quality (PQ)
issues associated with the interconnection and protection sys-
tems associated with large PV installations. CIGRE working
group C 4.29 has been discussing, analyzing and compiling
such issues since 2013 and their report on the same [1] is
an excellent reference for the interested reader. Utility expe-
riences with such Power Quality issues have been compiled
in [5], [6] and [7]. This paper reports two case studies on
PQ problems caused by PV transformer energization that have
been observed by industrial consumers located in the vicinity
of solar PV installations. A third case study, was carried out
in simulation, to understand the effect of resonance that gets
excited by PV transformer energization at the transmission
level. This list of issues is not intended to be exhaustive. The
rest of the paper is laid out as follows:
• Section II: Layout of a typical PV installation
• Section III: Case study 1: V oltage unbalance and reso-
nance problems exacerbated by transformer energization.
• Section IV: Case study 2: Zero crossing distortion caused
by ringing during transformer energization.
• Section V: Case study 3: Simulation analysis of resonance
with transmission cables that gets excited by PV trans-
former energization.
• Section VI: Conclusions and scope for further work.
II. S OLAR PV INSTALLATION
Solar PV infrastructure can be installed at the consumer volt-
age level (behind-the-metre systems) or at the sub-transmission
or distribution voltage level (utility level systems). The layout
of a typical utility level solar PV installation is shown in Fig.
1
Fig. 1. Layout of a single stage of a typical grid-tied, utility level PV
installation.
Generally, such installations have multiple inverters
(connected to PV arrays), connected in cascade to the grid
via step-up transformers. Fig. 1 shows one ‘stage’ of PV
generation. Generally, solar farms have multiple such ‘stages’.

Consequently, instead of having one large transformer, solar
farms tend to have multiple smaller transformers, tied to
inverters and PV arrays. These stages are then connected in
cascade. The ﬁrst two case studies presented here are issues
reported by utilities that were caused by the simultaneous
energization of these transformers. The third case study was
done in simulation to understand the effects of PV transformer
excited resonance issues on the transmission grid.
III. C ASE STUDY 1
Case 1 was reported by a utility, where re-energization of
a solar farm following a disturbance caused industrial loads
to trip elsewhere on the feeder. On the surface, the problem
appeared to be a straightforward consequence of transformer
inrush. Further investigation, however, revealed elevated levels
of harmonic voltages, caused by a combination of transformer
energization, unbalance and resonance, to be the root cause.
A single line diagram of the system is shown in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2. Single line diagram of system with location of solar farm and affected
industrial customer highlighted.
The solar farm was connected to the distribution grid using
twelve transformers (wye grounded-wye) with a power han-
dling capacity of 1670 kVAeach. The distribution transformer
has a power capacity of 25 MVA(115 kV/23 kV) while the
system has capacitors connected in the vicinity of both, the
solar farm and the industrial customer. V oltage and current
were measured on the low side of the distribution transformer,
at the 23 kV bus. The industrial customer was supplied at
a voltage level of 12.5 kV that was then stepped down to
4.16 kV. Twenty two transformers then stepped the voltage
down to 480 V. The control equipment in the industrial facility
was powered through a mix of 480/120 V, 480 Vto 24 VDC
and 120 Vto 24 VDC transformations.
A. Timeline of Events
A fault downstream of the solar farm shown in Fig. 2
caused downstream load to trip. The fault then caused the
undervoltage protection at the solar farm to trip ofﬂine. This
is shown in Fig. 3 which shows a snapshot of current and
voltage measurements.This event shall be referred to as ‘event
1’ in the rest of the relevant sections.

From Fig. 3, it can be seen that the fault occurs at 0.01 s

At about 0.36 s, protective devices operate and the solar farm

is energized. A slight swell, from the pre-fault voltage is
observed in the measurement snapshot. However, neither the

Following the energization of downstream load, the protec-

the farm exactly 3 minutes after downstream load energization.
During this period, the inverters were kept ofﬂine i.e. the
low side of the transformer was kept open. The solar farm

2 shows a slight DC offset and a swell in magnitude based

The time domain data of the two events is presented in

B. Frequency domain analysis
A spectrogram is a visual representation of frequency do-
main data, as it varies with time. In essence, a spectrogram
is implemented as an intensity plot (using a logarithmic
scale) of the Short Time Fourier Transform (STFT). In this
case, the signal was sampled at a speed of 128 samples per
cycle (7.68 kHz). The phase A voltage from both events was
analyzed ﬁrst and has been shown in Fig. 5.

Fig. 5. Phase A voltage spectrogram for event 1 (left) and event 2 (right).
The voltage in both events contains second, third, fourth
and ﬁfth harmonics as the dominant elements. The second har-
monic, characteristic of transformer energization, dampens out
in < 1 s. However, the ﬁfth harmonic is dominant throughout
the measurement event and has the second highest magnitude
(after the fundamental). The color of the harmonic frequency
indicates its relative magnitude, with blue being the lowest and
yellow being the highest magnitude. The voltage spectra, thus
demonstrate little difference between the two events in terms
of frequency signature. However, this is not the case with the
current spectra, shown in Fig. 6.

Fig. 6. Phase A current spectrogram for event 1 (left) and event 2 (right).
The even harmonic current dampens out within 0.5 s in
event 2, indicating absence of sympathetic inrush current
from the distribution transformer. In the case of event 1, the
fundamental and third harmonic current are the dominant
elements. However, in the case of event 2, the fundamental
and ﬁfth harmonic elements dominate, with the third harmonic
being present to a lesser extent. In order to have clarity on
the relative magnitude of the harmonic currents, FFT was
performed on the phase A current waveforms from event 1
and event 2.
The instantaneous maximum amplitude for the ﬁfth har-
monic current was observed to be about 25% of the funda-
mental current while that of the third harmonic current was
about 55% of fundamental. However, the FFT gives a ‘static’
image of the frequency. In other words, the FFT only indicates
the relative maximum amplitude of each frequency (even if
this maximum amplitude is momentary). What the FFT fails
to show, unlike the Spectrogram, is that the ﬁfth harmonic is
persistently present with a relatively large amplitude, through-
out the measurement window. The system is simply unable to
dampen out the magnitude of the ﬁfth harmonic current during
the 2 smeasurement window.
The dramatic jump in ﬁfth harmonic current magnitude
between the two events (as indicated by the FFT) and the long
time required to dampen out the ﬁfth harmonic as indicated
by the spectrogram, suggested that the system had a resonant
point near the ﬁfth harmonic frequency. The absence of a
dominant ﬁfth harmonic element in event 1 (and the presence
of it in event 2) current indicated that the transformer ener-
gization had managed to excite this resonance. Transformer
magnetizing current is naturally rich in harmonics and thus,
ﬁrst excites, and then sustains this resonance. A simulation of
the system, performed in Open DSS software, shows (Fig. 7)
that the system has a resonant point near the sixth harmonic
for the positive sequence and near the ﬁfth harmonic for
the zero sequence current. The transformer impedance during
energization, will have a small inﬂuence on this resonant
point, so that the resonance would be seen closer to the ﬁfth
harmonic for the zero sequence (since the transformer has a
wye grounded-wye conﬁguration).
Another aspect of the issue that emerges from an inspection
of Fig. 7 is that the zero sequence network has a resonant
frequency near the ﬁfth harmonic. The reader may recall that
the ﬁfth harmonic is, in fact, a negative sequence harmonic.
This highlights an important issue. The application of the
Fortescue transformation to decompose a set of phasors into
positive, negative and zero sequence components, assumes a
balanced set of phasors. However, if the phasors are unbal-
anced, then the traditional deﬁnitions of positive, negative and
zero sequence do not hold. In other words, for an unbalanced
set of voltages or currents, the ﬁfth harmonic can no longer
be considered to be a negative sequence harmonic. For 3-
phase distribution systems, a slight unbalance in the voltages
always exists. Unbalanced events (such as a large single
phase load energization. e.g. Arc furnace) can exacerbate the
problem even further. The interested reader may refer to [8]
for a more detailed understanding of the impact of unbalance
on harmonic analyses. Fig. 8 shows plots of single cycle
RMS values of inrush current, following energization. The

Due to this unbalance, ﬁfth harmonic current no longer adds

neutral conductors, which provide a low impedance path. Thus,
unbalance causes frequencies other than the triplen harmonics
to show up in a zero sequence frequency scan. The unbalance
in the system thus exacerbates the issue. This observation
also highlights the importance of running simulations with
three phase models rather than simply using a single phase
or positive sequence representation of the circuit.

As a ﬁnal note, it is unknown as to whether it was distortion
around the zero crossing, thermal overload due to harmonics
or sustained unbalance that caused the load to trip. The load
managed to ride through the voltage sags due to event 1 but
lack of PQ monitors at the customer site hinder us from
identifying speciﬁc PQ aspects of event 2 that caused load
tripping.
IV. C ASE STUDY 2
As noted previously, this case is similar to Case 1, in the
sense that the energization of PV transformers caused indus-
trial load to trip. However, unlike Case 1 (where harmonic
resonance and system unbalance were the main contributing
factors), in Case 2 transformer energization caused voltage
distortion around the zero crossing of the fundamental voltage
which ultimately caused industrial adjustable speed drives to
trip ofﬂine. A single line diagram of the system, provided
by the utility, is shown in Fig. 9. As shown, the Solar Farm
is located in the vicinity of a Steel Plant. Quite like case 1,
the composition of load and its topology at the plant were
unknown.
Fig. 9. Single line diagram of the system showing the location of the Solar
farm and the Steel Plant.
The solar farm was connected to the utility via eight
transformers (wye grounded-wye) of 1400 kVAcapacity each.
A 600 kvarcapacitor bank was connected near the solar farm
for voltage support. The utility conducted tests to see if the
energization of PV transformers caused any problems at the
steel plant (and monitored the PQ at the plant for the same).
During energization, ringing between the transformers and the
nearby capacitor bank were observed. The voltage and current
waveforms, recorded at the solar farm are shown in Fig. 10.
The worst case voltage sag resulting from the energization
caused single phase voltage at the steel plant to get reduced
to about 78% of its nominal value. The plant load was able
to ride through these sags. However, during some energizing
events, it was discovered that the multiple zero crossings due to
harmonics (resulting from the ringing) 9, 10 and 11 caused DC
drives to trip ofﬂine. DC drives are typically line commutated,
using SCRs for their switching. The presence of multiple zero
crossings in the line voltage causes the circuits in such drives
to commutate prematurely and trip ofﬂine. This was observed
to be the case here. In other cases, it was observed that AC
drives (fed through a dedicated DC power supply) tripped
ofﬂine due to overvoltage. This can most likely be attributed

In each of case 1 and case 2, the utilities staggered the
energization of the transformers. This was found to ﬁx the
issue as it reduced the total magnitude of energization inrush
current (and hence reduced chances of exciting a resonance)
for case 1 and the total inductance seen by the capacitor bank
for case 2. However, utilities reported this ﬁx to be expensive
as it required changes in existing infrastructure. Other possible
solutions and future work in this area have been laid out in
the last section of this paper.
V. C ASE STUDY 3
As seen in the previous sections, the spectrum of trans-
former inrush current tends to be concentrated at low order
harmonics, below the ﬁrst harmonic resonance frequency of
most transmission grids. The main cases where resonance at
these frequencies may be introduced is due to large shunt
capacitance such as capacitor banks, ﬁlter banks or long
underground cables. In many countries cable networks are
used extensively in relation to the connection of solar PV due
to their reduced visual impact. If a transformer is energized
at a network location with low-order harmonic resonance,
the inrush current may excite a resonance condition giving
rise to temporary overvoltages or severe, short-lived harmonic
distortion [10]. As large capacitor banks and long underground
cables have very low losses, these overvoltages may persist for
hundreds of milliseconds or longer. While these overvoltages
may be within the design capabilities of grid assets, they
may be outside of inverter high voltage ride-through require-
ments resulting in unscheduled disconnection of solar PV or
other inverter-interfaced generation. The presence of severe
harmonic distortion may also excite harmonic instability in
nearby inverters, which could also lead to disconnection of
the solar PV generation [11].
To examine this issue a network was composed using
EMTP-RV software. The network consists of an area of
115 kVgrid with a 20 kmXLPE cable terminating at a busbar
with two transformers, both serving solar PV sites as shown in
Fig. 11. The solar PV inverters are modeled to include internal
control systems (inner control loops for dq-frame control as
well as outer control loop power control), inverter voltage and
frequency protection, inverter harmonic ﬁlter, and solar PV
farm cable network impedance. The aim of the study was to
investigate the temporary overvoltages and harmonics which
may occur immediately after transformer energization.
Fig. 11. Simpliﬁed one line diagram of test network used to examine Cable-
Transformer inrush resonance. Note that ‘OHL’ stands for Overhead Line.
The cable consists of three single-core cables with copper
conductors, XLPE insulation and cross-bonded sheaths. A
zero and positive-sequence impedance-frequency plot of the
network as seen by the 115 kVside of the solar PV busbars is
shown in Fig. 12. The low-order resonance near 250 Hzdue
to the cable can be clearly seen.

When the 115 kVtransformer circuit breaker is closed to en-
ergize the unloaded Solar Farm #1 transformer at t = 120 ms,
the inrush current can be seen to excite a resonance with the
capacitance of the cable. This gives rise to temporary over-
voltages in excess of 1.25 puas illustrated by Fig. 13.
The overvoltage is seen to decay over the course of a few
seconds. However, the initial magnitude is sufﬁcient to breach
the inverter over-voltage ride-through limit resulting in it trip-
ping 0.16 slater. In order to provide satisfactory performance
in response to voltage sags, frequency excursions and other
dynamic events inverter controllers require bandwidths of up
to 1 kHz. The frequency response of these control loops may
itself exhibit resonances which can be excited in the presence
of sufﬁcient harmonic distortion [11]. The magnitude of the
harmonic distortion after transformer energization is sufﬁcient
to excite a resonance in the inverter control loops.
The inrush current on transformer #1 also excites sympa-
thetic inrush [12] on transformer #2, which can be seen to

This case has illustrated the potential causes and impacts
of temporary overvoltages arising due to transformer inrush
exciting transmission grid harmonic resonances. Such tempo-
rary overvoltages can result in inverters disconnecting due to
harmonic instability or breaching of over-voltage ride-through
capabilities.
VI. C ONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
A. Conclusions
The case studies shown in the paper lead to the following
broad conclusions:
• Energization of solar farms can have a negative impact
on power quality and cause disruption or disconnection
of customer load. This is especially the case where the
transformer inrush current causes severe voltage distor-
tion.
• V oltage distortion may occur due to the magnitude of the
inrush current of energizing multiple transformer simulta-
neously or where the inrush current excites existing low
frequency resonances in the network.
• In studying these phenomena it is critical to ensure that
zero sequence impedance is represented and, preferably,
phase-domain models of lines and cables are used. During
transformer inrush the grid voltage and current may
become severely unbalanced, so grid models which only
include positive sequence impedances will yield inaccu-
rate or misleading results.
B. Future Work
Based upon the work done for these case studies, the
following avenues for future research were identiﬁed:
• Estimating the contribution of inverter interfaces to volt-
age distortion, both in the low frequency (up to 2 kHz)
and the supraharmonic ( 2 to 150 kHz) frequency range
using improved models or nearby measurements.
• Analyze the relative sizes of solar PV farms with regards
to the grid and try to standardize these using DER
interconnection standards.
• Work with utilities to study resonance issues for future
PV installations during the planning stage. In the case
of existing installations, solutions to ﬁx resonance issues
need to be worked upon.
• Develop a better understanding of available and proposed
transformer inrush mitigation technologies.
